metadata.case_name: E. D. Sassoon Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: A partnership firm comprising members of the Sassoon family carried on business under the name E. D. Sassoon Co. prior to 1920 at Bombay, Calcutta, Karachi, Hongkong, Shanghai, London, Manchester, Basra and Persian Gulf as bankers, commission agents, dealers in shares and securities, foreign exchange etc.
In accounting year 1919, the firm incurred net loss of Rs. 12,37,413-12-2.
In 1920, the firm made large profits mostly in London Exchange Account and claimed depreciation in shares and securities amounting to Rs. 9,26,730-5-8.

On 8th September 1920, Bombay Trust Corporation Ltd. (B.T.C.) incorporated in Bombay, carrying on business as dealers in shares, securities and foreign exchange. By end of December 1920, investments Rs. 3,23,78,494/-; end 1921 Rs. 4,31,32,212/-; end 1922 Rs. 10,43,78,511/-.
On 4th December 1920, E. D. Sassoon Co. Ltd. (assessee company) incorporated in Bombay with object to acquire and take over the business of the firm as a going concern.

Agreement executed on 30th June 1921 by assessee company to purchase firm's business and assets including shares and debentures at market price on 31st December 1920. Took over shares and securities worth Rs. 1,93,79,521-3-1 at market value as on 31.12.1920.
Between 1st January 1921 to 31st December 1921, assessee purchased further shares and securities worth Rs. 4,28,05,627/- in ordinary course of business.

In accounting year 1921, Income-tax Officer noted no dealing in shares and securities by assessee. At end of 1921, valued securities at market rates showing appreciation of Rs. 9,26,713/-, which was deleted from computation of income.
Examiner of accounts on 12th October 1922 noted firm was habitual dealer in shares, set off loss in 1920, so appreciation Rs. 9,27,708-6-7 to be taxed.
Income-tax Officer on 23rd December 1922 endorsed to disregard appreciation as shares taken over by new company B.T.C. Ltd. on instructions.
Firm assessed for 1921-22 under Income-tax Act 1918 on income of accounting year 1921. Assessee assessed 1922-23 to 1948-49 under Act of 1922.
In assessment year 1949-50, assessee discontinued business on 28th December 1948 (went into liquidation) and claimed exemption on Rs. 33,40,057/- under S.25(3).
Income-tax Officer rejected claim: (1) assessee claimed deduction of appreciation Rs. 9,26,708/- in 1921; (2) discontinued dealing in stocks and shares.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner held business of share dealings not charged to tax under 1918 Act for 1918-1921.
Tribunal held firm assessed under 1918 Act but assessee did not intend to do or take over business of dealing in securities from firm.

Five questions referred to Bombay High Court under S.66(1): (1) Entitled to exemption u/s 25(3)? (2) Loss on Shanghai property allowable? (3) Deduct Rs.3,70,943/- to Superannuation Fund? (4) Claim Rs.2,92,672/- transferred after liquidation? (5) Set off loss Rs.3,28,825/- of 1948 against 1949-50 profit?
High Court answered four questions (1,3,4,5) in favour of assessee, question 2 in favour of revenue. Judgment dated 13,14,16 October 1967.
For 1918: Firm assessed under 1918 Act. 1919: Huge loss, no tax. 1920: Huge profit, losses on revaluation allowed, firm treated as dealer.
Assessee's business activities from incorporation to liquidation included dealings in shares and securities.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessee company is entitled to claim exemption under Section 25(3) of the Act?
Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the loss suffered on the sale of property in Shanghai was allowable as a revenue deduction out of profits of the year?
Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessee company is entitled to deduct Rs. 3,70,943/- the amount transferred to the Superannuation Fund against income of the year?

Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessee company is entitled to claim a sum of Rs. 2,92,672/- transferred after the liquidation of the company as against the profits of the company?
Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the assessee company is entitled to set off the loss of Rs. 3,28,825/- suffered in 1948 as against profit of 1949-50?

petitioner_arguments.text: Assessee took over entire business of firm as going concern including dealing in shares and stocks; purchased further shares in ordinary course; treated as trader in assessments; entitled to relief u/s 25(3) as predecessor firm charged under 1918 Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 25(3) Income-tax Act 1922; Memorandum of Association

petitioner_arguments.text: Income-tax Officer omitted to tax appreciation in 1921 despite examiner's note, but this does not mean no dealing; shares transferred to assessee not B.T.C.

respondent_arguments.text: Assessee did not carry on same business as firm; did not take over or intend to do dealing in shares/securities; held as investments for B.T.C.; share dealings not charged under 1918 Act; discontinued only one business.
In 1921, appreciation deleted and dividends assessed in B.T.C.; firm not charged on share dealings in 1918-1921.

court_reasoning.text: To claim relief u/s 25(3): (1) business charged under 1918 Act; (2) no succession u/s 25(4); (3) complete discontinuance. Firm was so charged; assessee took over as going concern including share dealing evidenced by purchases, valuations, assessments.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee carried on same business as firm; shares transferred to assessee not B.T.C.; no evidence held only as investment.

court_reasoning.text: S.25(3) applies to business charged under 1918 Act even if successor; exemption not limited to specific heads or activities; even if some discontinued, overall business qualifies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Relief general, not restricted to income under particular head.

court_reasoning.text: Tribunal findings conflicted; High Court correctly held assessee traded in shares post-takeover based on assessment orders and material.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sufficient material shows dealing in shares.

holdings.text: Assessee entitled to relief under Section 25(3) as business was charged under 1918 Act via predecessor firm and fully discontinued.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. P.E. Polson
precedents_cited.relevance: Purpose of s.25(3) to avoid double taxation due to change in assessment basis from 1918 to 1922 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Executors of Estate of Dubash v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City-I v. Chugandas Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Exemption under s.25(3) general, not restricted to income under specific head; applies to business charged under 1918 Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: O.R.M. SP. SV. Firm v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Chugandas on scope of s.25(3).

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1918
statutes_cited.relevance: Business charged under this Act qualifies for relief on discontinuance under 1922 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: S.25(3) provides relief on discontinuance of business charged under 1918 Act; conditions for exemption.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court confirmed High Court judgment on question 1, holding assessee entitled to exemption under S.25(3). No arguments addressed on other questions. High Court had favored assessee on four questions, revenue on second.
outcome.relief_granted: Exemption under Section 25(3) granted to assessee.

key_quotes.text: An assessee to obtain relief under the above sub-section has to satisfy three conditions. Firstly, that the business, profession or vocation must be one on which tax was at any time charged under the 1918 Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The exemption under section 25(3) is general, it is not restricted to income chargeable under section 10 of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Broad scope of exemption not limited to specific income heads.

key_quotes.text: It appears to us that in any view of the matter the assessee company was entitled to relief under section 25(3), as such, the judgement of the High Court has to be confirmed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
